content:
The philosophy of existentialism emerged in the 19th century as a reaction to traditional philosophical ideas about the nature of human existence. Existentialists, such as Friedrich Nietzsche and Jean-Paul Sartre, emphasized individual freedom, choice, and subjective experience over universal truths. They argued that life has no inherent meaning, and it is up to each individual to create their own purpose. This philosophy has had a significant influence on a wide range of disciplines, including literature, psychology, and political theory. Which philosophical school does existentialism most directly challenge?
A. Empiricism
B. Rationalism
C. Stoicism
D. Utilitarianism

Existentialism most directly challenges Rationalism. Rationalism is a philosophical school that emphasizes reason and intellect as the primary sources of knowledge and truth. Existentialists, on the other hand, focus on individual experience, emotion, and subjective interpretation of reality. They argue that universal truths and objective reality are less important than personal experience and individual choice.
